Leveraging advertising to a higher dimension: experimental research on the impact of virtual reality on brand personality impressions

Abstract

As new advertising formats emerge, research regarding their effectiveness is called for. Since the emergence of virtual reality (VR) technology, several brands have started implementing VR advertising in their communication strategies. The research objective of this study is to examine whether mobile VR advertising can positively impact managerially relevant brand outcome variables [brand personality (BP) impressions, brand attitude and purchase intentions] compared to traditional 2D advertising. An experimental between-subjects design comprising 160 respondents reveals a significant difference in impact between 2D and VR advertising on three out of five BP dimensions (namely ‘excitement’, ‘sophistication’ and a marginal effect on ‘ruggedness’). Furthermore, mobile VR advertising evokes significantly more positive consumer attitudes and higher purchase intentions than mobile 2D ads. The findings of this study imply that mobile VR advertising can be effective for brand managers who are in search of bringing their brands to life and who aim to obtain more positive consumer attitudes and higher purchase intentions towards their brands.

Introduction

Virtual reality (VR) technology has recently been proclaimed as the most promising emerging technology at present for businesses to gain a competitive advantage (Gartner 2016) and as the next big thing in advertising (Crabtree 2016; King 2017). VR allows a user to be immersed in—and interact with—a realistic, computer-generated environment (Borsci et al. 2016; Sharar et al. 2008). Unlike traditional 3D product advertising (cf. Choi and Taylor 2014; Debbabi et al. 2010; Edwards and Gangadharbatla 2001), VR no longer confines users to simple ‘mouse clicks’ on a computer screen to interact with products (e.g. enlarging or rotating them to get a better view), but they can actually view and experience the products or brands in a virtual setting while being immersed in that specific scenery. For example, Volvo launched a Google Cardboard VR app for its limited edition XC90 model (Dua 2014). This app enables users to take a virtual test drive in the car and to try out various interior configurations without leaving their homes. The Marriott International hotel chain has also jumped on the ‘VR train’ by launching a multi-sensory VR travel experience (Mandelbaum 2015) that allows users to ‘travel’ to different destinations via the VR headset while being immersed in the scenery of the chosen destination, accompanied with local sounds and even a touch of sun on the skin or the feeling of a summer breeze for a realistic experience. This particular initiative takes the VR experience even further by adding sensory stimuli, such as heat and mist. Even without this sensory enrichment, VR advertising has the potential to provide a much richer experience than mere 3D product advertising, due to its immersive nature. Consequently, this new way of advertising takes advertising to a whole new level, which can facilitate the transfer of hedonic benefits from the brand to the consumer (Hartmann et al. 2010; Sherry 2004).

Implementing VR in communication strategies can be particularly interesting for experience brands, such as apparel brands, due to the fact that the creation of imagery is a key driver for such brands to achieve consumer recognition and interest (Kim 2000; Lau and Lee 2016). Because of its exceptional vividness, which intensifies the power of the portrayed imagery (Overmars and Poels 2015; Van Kerrebroeck et al. 2017a), VR advertising can reinforce the creation of strong, favourable and unique brand associations (Keller 2001). This can be valuable for brand managers in search of bringing their brands to life by building brand personality (BP). The concept of BP, which has become increasingly important for differentiation in branding (Jin 2010), refers to the ‘set of human personality traits that are also applicable to and relevant for brands’ (Azoulay and Kapferer 2003, p. 151). This notion of BP is strongly related to the phenomenon of anthropomorphism, or ‘the tendency to imbue nonhuman agents with humanlike characteristics, motivations, intentions, or emotions’ (Epley et al. 2007, p. 864). Consumers can actually see brands as living humanlike entities (Avis 2011), which is an important basis for the formation of consumer–brand relationships (Fournier 1998). In particular, a well-established BP helps consumers express themselves (Aaker 1997, 1999) by buying brands that are congruent with their self-image (Sirgy 1982). Therefore, brand managers are striving to imbue their brands with humanlike characteristics, which should correspond to the actual or desired personality profile of the consumer target group to attract them to the brand (Malär et al. 2012). As VR provides a vivid and sensorially rich medium (Steuer 1992), it can enable brand managers to infuse more life into their brands by vividly displaying the brand and its brand imagery and personality characteristics or by providing a vivid brand experience. It has been established that vivid representations and enhanced brand experiences are a driver of BP (Brakus et al. 2009). So, if VR equips brand managers with a means to clearly convey their brand’s personality to consumers, it can be expected that the medium also contributes to generating more positive brand attitudes and higher purchase intentions. As such, the purpose and novelty of this study is to measure to what extent a VR brand experience (which we consider to be an enhanced brand experience, compared to a brand experience via traditional 2D video) helps construe the five anthropomorphic BP traits in consumers’ minds and thus contributes to more favourable brand attitudes and purchase intentions.

The contribution to the available literature is threefold. First, as VR technology and applications are rapidly developing and VR marketing research is still very much in its infancy, more grounded interdisciplinary research is called for to better assess the full potential of this technology (Bonetti et al. 2018). Also, more specifically in an advertising context, King (2017) claims that while Advertising Age declared VR as the Next Big Thing in its 2016 July issue covering the Cannes Lions Experience (AdAge 2016), more knowledge is needed on how to use VR ‘to tell brand stories’. So far, studies on VR in an advertising context mainly focused on informational/functional advertising appeals (i.e. bringing across product attributes), while the potential of VR for transformational advertising appeals (i.e. providing a brand experience to build brand imagery) appears largely unexplored (see Van Kerrebroeck et al. 2017a for an overview). As it has been shown that in developed markets it is notably this latter, experiential route that drives persuasion (Zarantonello et al. 2013), this study embarks on exploring this promising avenue for VR advertising by looking at its impact on the BP construct, brand attitudes and subsequent purchase intentions. While several antecedents of the BP construct have already been studied (Eisend and Stokburger-Sauer 2013), among which are the usage of augmented reality (AR) or the portrayal of 3D virtual objects in real environments in real time (Stoyanova et al. 2015), and in-game 3D advertising (Lee et al. 2017), the potential of VR to bring brands to life has not yet been examined, which underscores a third important contribution of this work.

In this paper, a theoretical backdrop is first provided, discussing the key concepts of VR and its applications in marketing and advertising. This section is followed by the research objectives and hypotheses based on the literature. Subsequent sections describe the methodology and approach of this study, as well as the findings of the experiment. Next, a discussion that includes theoretical and practical implications is provided. Finally, the limitations of the research are addressed, and suggestions for further research are provided.

Theoretical backdrop

Virtual reality as an advertising medium

VR technology is defined by Steuer (1992) as a ‘simulated environment in which a perceiver experiences telepresence’ (pp. 76–77). Telepresence occurs when a user experiences presence in the portrayed environment while using a certain medium and is composed of two determinants. The first determinant, ‘vividness’, refers to ‘the representational richness of a mediated environment’ (Steuer 1992, p. 11), while the second determinant, ‘interactivity’, refers to ‘the extent to which users can participate in modifying form and content of a mediated environment in real time’ (Steuer 1992, p. 14). Such feelings of presence, or ‘the perception of actually being there’ (Mikropoulos 2006; Sheridan 1992), emerge when a user perceiving or interacting with a medium feels totally immersed in the human–computer environment (Borsci et al. 2016). Immersion can be referred to as a psychological state in which a user feels isolated from the real world by means of the virtual environment (Witmer and Singer 1998).

So far, VR marketing applications fall short in terms of interactivity, as there is still little possibility for interaction with the presented environments (Van Kerrebroeck et al. 2017a). As such, vividness, which is also interchangeably referred to as immersion (Walsh and Pawlowski 2002), appears to be the most important feature of VR for advertising. Vividness can be further dichotomized into ‘breadth’ (i.e. ‘the number of sensory dimensions simultaneously presented’ [Steuer 1992, p. 11]) and ‘depth’ (i.e. ‘the quality and resolution of the presentation’ [Fortin and Dholakia 2005, p. 389]). Contrary to 2D and 3D environments, VR environments offer a wider and more profound experience (Chen et al. 1998). For example, VR provides not only multi-sensory stimulation, such as vision and sound, but also proprioceptor-based stimulation (e.g. being able to look and move around and the sensation of falling) (Sanchez-Vives and Slater 2005). Given the broad range of sensory stimulation, the use of VR-mediated environments for advertising purposes, and more specifically for brand experiences, can evoke stronger brand-related imagery in consumers’ minds (Brakus et al. 2009).

It is important to note the difference between VR and 3D product advertising. The fact that the user can be immersed in a mediated environment through VR advertising makes a profound difference with what is often referred to as 3D (product) advertising. The latter provides the possibility to, for example, point and click on certain products or interact with them at best (e.g. enlarging or rotating products) (cf. Choi and Taylor 2014; Debbabi et al. 2010; Li et al. 2001). In this sense, 3D product advertising and VR advertising are considered two separate concepts, with the focus of this study being on the latter.

Finally, due to its true full screen display technology, the VR medium is able to block out the real surrounding environment, causing a higher level of immersion in the ad. The mere fact that a VR headset is fully encompassing a viewer’s sight also causes less distractions from the outside world, which makes a considerable difference as compared to other advertising media, where distractions are practically inevitable in the multi-screen world we live in today (Segijn et al. 2017), with a deteriorating impact on advertising effectiveness (Garaus et al. 2017).

Virtual reality in marketing

While VR is slowly infiltrating the mass market, its application for marketing purposes is still in its infancy (Barnes 2016; Van Kerrebroeck et al. 2017b). Nevertheless, despite the relatively recent emergence of the technology for consumer markets, various well-known brands are already jumping on the bandwagon of virtual brand experiences. For example, Coca-Cola took its yearly Christmas advertising to a different dimension by letting the customers experience a virtual sleigh ride with Santa (Mybryonic 2016). Hundreds of Coca-Cola trucks were sent to different cities to immerse passengers in the virtual Christmas ad. Such types of VR pop-up experiences can be valuable for a brand to attract its target audience’s attention and to build brand awareness, as well as to ensure that the brand stays relevant and top of mind (i.e. reminder advertising). Another brand in the food industry that has jumped on the VR bandwagon is Boursin cream cheese. To improve its brand awareness, Boursin chose to implement a VR experience including VR footage that allows users to ‘travel’ through the refrigerator (Davis 2016). While this VR experience was provided at certain pop-up locations, the VR video was also made available to consumers at home via YouTubeFootnote 1 and can easily be watched with a smartphone-enabled VR headset. In the fashion industry, Adidas recently set up a VR video experience in their New York store featuring NBA player James Harden (Alvarez 2016). This is an example of VR being used in flagship stores with the goal of building brand image and consequently driving more sales (Ataman and Ülengin 2003). Additionally, VR experiences can also be offered by retailers (e.g. MediaMarkt) to attract shoppers or can serve as a way to provide relaxation in a crowded shopping mall environment (Van Kerrebroeck et al. 2017b). IKEA is even conceptualizing virtual showrooms to visualize its notorious catalogue to create new customer experiences and eventually save up on retail space (Chodorge 2018). Based on these examples, it is clear that VR is being implemented in marketing campaigns in different ways, depending on the goal the brand wants to reach with its brand communications.

To effectively set up a VR marketing campaign, there is a need for (1) a clear strategy or goal, (2) content (e.g. the story a brand wants to convey with its ad), (3) software (e.g. a VR application running the content) and (4) hardware (e.g. a VR-enabled headset). Head-mounted VR devices currently come in two categories. If the brand’s goal is to provide high-quality content for building brand imagery among an audience that is already in a shopping mindset at the point of sale, more premium, computer-driven headsets with built-in screen, such as the Oculus Rift or PlayStation VR, are advised. These more sophisticated VR experiences provide a more pronounced proprioceptor stimulation to enhance the brand experience offered in stores or at pop-up locations. For example, Oculus Rift and Touch provide the user two joysticks that enable natural hand usage in the mediated environment (Microsoft 2018). It has been proven that by including additional sensory stimulation, such as tactile feedback, a higher sense of presence can be achieved, which improves the efficacy of the medium (Jin 2010). However, if a brand’s goal is mainly to attract a broad consumer audience to build brand awareness, the focus should be on providing content that users can watch independently, at home or on the go, via much cheaper, smartphone-enabled headsets, which require a smartphone to be inserted as a screen. As Google Cardboard-like devices can already be obtained for less than 15 US dollars, such VR headsets have become very affordable for a broad audience. In 2016, McDonald’s even allowed its customers to transform their iconic Happy Meal box into a foldable smartphone-enabled headset (Murphy 2016). As ever-cheaper alternatives become available, the cost barrier for consumers keeps decreasing, extending the possible reach of the medium.

With respect to VR content, brand communication campaigns can be either informational or transformational (i.e. experience based) (Puto and Wells 1984; Zarantonello et al. 2013). On the one hand, if the purpose of the communication strategy is to inform the customer (i.e. informational brand communications), the interactivity of the medium appears to be of the most importance (Van Kerrebroeck 2017). For example, Google culture’s app (Field 2017) provides users the possibility to visit more than 1200 museums, providing information about the exhibitions in a fun way. On the other hand, if the brand’s communication strategy is built to provide an entertaining experience to the customer, the vividness of the medium appears to be of the most importance to immerse the user (Van Kerrebroeck et al. 2017b). For example, a New York travel experience in VR (Barack 2016) provides the user the feeling of visiting that particular city by immersing the user in the portrayed environment. As VR content has the possibility to provide both interactivity and vividness, brand managers should focus differently on these two aspects depending on the type of communication they want to convey to the consumer (i.e. either interactivity for informational content or vividness for transformational content).

As VR technology is expected to become more available and affordable to the mass market in the coming years (Alcántara 2016; Gartner 2017), brands should take this new way of advertising into consideration and gain inspiration from the current pioneers in VR marketing. According to Gartner (2017) Hype Cycle for emerging technologies, VR is projected to reach its full potential only in 2–5 years and will be enhanced with additional output (e.g. haptics or scents) in the near future. Aside from the implementation of VR in offline facilities, such as shopping malls and pop-up or flagship stores, VR can also serve to enhance the digital consumer experience in the online retail channel. The technology can be used to enhance the remote retail experience and, as such, can redefine online shopping at people’s homes (e.g. allowing them to walk through a virtual car showroom). Online shopping is growing enormously, as global online sales comprised 2290 trillion US dollars and is expected to almost double by 2021 (Statista 2017). VR can be used as a facilitator to increase online sales by combining some of the merits of both on- and offline shopping (Landicho 2017). For example, VR provides a way of presenting the products as if they were real (e.g. scrolling through a library of virtually presented products that can be inspected from all sides) in the comfort of your own home. This way, the risk barrier to buy online can be lowered, as VR allows sellers to better inform the consumer about their products. If consumers are better informed of what they can expect from the product upon making a purchase decision, this will positively impact return rates (Petersen and Kumar 2015), as fewer consumers will be dissatisfied upon receiving the product at home. As smartphone-operated VR headsets (such as Google Cardboard) have become very affordable to the general public, these kinds of devices are expected to get widely adopted in the near future. While more and more consumers are using their smartphones to make purchases online (Wang et al. 2015), mobile commerce is expected to include more than half of all e-commerce transactions (Statista 2017). As such, brands have the asset to target the ubiquitous consumer on the go (Muzellec and O’Raghallaigh 2017) while combining the merits of on- and offline shopping. Such a mobile VR strategy can be implemented by either investing in a dedicated VR application (cf. Discovery VR app) or making a VR video that can be watched on YouTube or the brand’s mobile website. Essentially, for both online and offline retail channels, VR technology enables marketers to submerge rather passive consumers into an active brand experience (Guppta 2015).

Brand personality

Conceptualization

The concept of BP is strongly related to the phenomenon of anthropomorphism or ‘the tendency to imbue nonhuman agents with humanlike characteristics, motivations, intentions, or emotions’ (Epley et al. 2007, p. 864). As such, not only people, but also brands can be ascribed with a specific character or personality on the basis of which consumer–brand relationships are formed (Fournier 1998). Essentially, if brands are perceived as being anthropomorphic, consumers actually see these brands as living, humanlike entities (Avis 2011). Building a certain BP helps differentiate a brand from its main competitors (Aaker 1997) and helps communicate the brand’s values (Keller 2009). Thus, brand managers are ascribing their brands humanlike characteristics that should correspond to the actual or desired personality profile of the consumer target group to attract them to the brand (Malär et al. 2012). These humanlike aspects of brands are being measured and studied with BP scales, such as the one developed by Aaker (1997).

Aaker defined BP as ‘the set of human characteristics associated with a brand’ (Aaker 1997, p. 347). She developed a BP scale, consisting of five distinct dimensions (in line with the big five of human personality): sincerity, excitement, competence, sophistication and ruggedness. The scale has been applied to a wide variety of brands in prior research, revealing for instance that Hallmark is perceived as ‘sincere’, while Levi’s is seen as ‘rugged’ (Brakus et al. 2009). Whereas Colgate comes across as ‘rugged’, ‘competent’ and ‘exciting’ (Sekar and Thomas 2008), L’Oréal is mainly perceived as ‘exciting’ and ‘sincere’ and is not considered ‘rugged’ at all (Dolatabadi et al. 2012). Aaker’s BP conceptualization and scale are widely accepted and have been extensively used in many academic studies (cf. the meta-analysis by Eisend and Stokburger-Sauer 2013) and have also been proven to be robust and generalizable over different product categories (Freling and Forbes 2005; Anandkumar and George 2011). With more than 8800 Web of Science citations (as of January 2018), it is the most extensively cited BP scale thus far. While there exist other useful BP scales [such as the ones conceived by Ferrandi et al. (2000), Caprara et al. (2001), Kim et al. (2001), Davies et al. (2004), Milas and Mlacic (2007) and Geuens et al. (2009)], they often involve slight contextual or cultural adaptations to the scale items and often include similar BP dimensions, revealing a large degree of overlap between these scales (Wijayanto 2015).

Although the concept of BP has recurrently been mixed up with brand identity and image (Meenaghan 1995), BP is in fact only a part, yet a major component, of a brand’s image (Nandan 2005; Geuens et al. 2009). While brand identity refers to what the company sends out, brand image is considered the resulting perceived conception of this identity in consumers’ minds (Nandan 2005). Consequently, BP is a concept that is perceived by the consumer within the encompassing brand image construct.

Over the last decade, the concept of BP has also been extended to other applications aside from product or BP, more specifically to online product BP (Park et al. 2005), travel destination personality (Hosany et al. 2006), store personality (d’Astous and Boujbel 2007) and even sporting event personality (Lee and Cho 2009). The continual stream of BP research reflects on the importance of this valuable concept in marketing.

Brand personality consequences

The ‘BP effect’ is defined by Freling and Forbes (2005) as ‘the direct influence that brand personality will have on a variety of consumer-driven outcomes’ (p. 1). So far, numerous studies have examined the benefits of a favourable BP on brand success variables, such as trust (Sung and Kim 2010; Hess et al. 2007), affect (Sung and Kim 2010), engagement (Goldsmith and Goldsmith 2012), attitude (Lee and Kang 2013; Grohmann 2009; Freling and Forbes 2005; Supphellen and Grønhaug 2003), perceived quality (Ramaseshan and Tsao 2007), brand equity (Valette-Florence et al. 2011), satisfaction (Brakus et al. 2009), attachment (Govers and Mugge 2004), consumer–brand relationship building (Fournier 1998), success of brand extensions (Freling and Forbes 2005), word-of-mouth communications (Grohmann 2009), purchase intentions (de la Toldos-Romero and Orozco-Gomez 2015; Eisend and Stokburger-Sauer 2013; Grohmann 2009), loyalty (Brakus et al. 2009; Grohmann 2009; Lin 2010) and actual purchase behaviour (Eisend and Stokburger-Sauer 2013).

Advertising characteristics as drivers of brand personality

While a strong BP can have a positive effect on different brand-related outcomes, it is also essential to know how such a BP can be triggered. In other words, it is necessary for brand managers to know how a favourable BP can be created to reap the rewards of their investments.

Advertising provides an important vehicle to convey a brand’s personality (Aaker 1997). An ad can, for example, focus on aspirational associations, such as upper class and glamorous, to portray a brand’s sophistication (e.g. Mercedes), it can glorify American ideals as strength and masculinity to convey a brand’s ruggedness (e.g. Marlboro), or it can use ordinary models to convey a brand’s sincerity (e.g. Dove). However, next to the content of such advertising, form and style also play an important role (Aaker 1997). Ang and Lim (2006), for example, found that brands using metaphors in ads were perceived to be more sophisticated and exciting but less sincere and competent than those using literal headlines or pictures.

Numerous scholars have examined an array of possible BP antecedents. In their meta-analysis, Eisend and Stokburger-Sauer (2013) identify three main advertising characteristics that brand managers should take into account to get the intended BP traits across: (1) complexity, (2) consistency and (3) the prevalence of hedonic benefit claims. More specifically, they found that desired BP perceptions are more effectively evoked in consumers’ minds when ads are (1) less complex and thus easier to understand, (2) more consistent and as such more coherent and (3) contain hedonic benefits, referring to the affective and sensory needs satisfied by the brand aside from the merely utilitarian ones. Because of the latter, the focus of this study will be on transformational or hedonic (as opposed to mere informational) advertising (see also Van Kerrebroeck et al. 2017a).

Brand experience as a driver of brand personality

In addition to the content and execution of brand advertising, actual brand experiences have also been found to evoke BP perceptions (Aaker 1997). According to Brakus et al. (2009), brand experiences involve (1) sensory, (2) affective, (3) intellectual and (4) behavioural consumer responses. First, the sensations include all the human senses that are affected as a result of a particular brand experience. This can include vision and hearing, as well as other senses. Second, brand experiences can be affective in case they induce feelings and sentiments in an individual with regard to the brand. Third, a brand experience can elicit a cognitive response in case it incites a person to think, be stimulated and feel more curious towards that specific brand. Fourth, behavioural responses refer to the bodily experience a person has as a result of the brand experience and may encourage physical actions and behaviours. When a particular brand experience affects more of these four underlying consumer responses, this more pronounced brand experience has been shown to lead to more enunciated BP associations, which in turn affect consumer satisfaction and loyalty (Brakus et al. 2009).

Research objectives and hypotheses

The research objective of this study is to examine whether the use of VR can elevate transformational advertising to a higher level of effectiveness in bringing brands to life and getting across BP impressions. More specifically, we want to investigate whether mobile VR advertising has a stronger impact compared to mobile 2D advertising on the following brand outcomes: (1) BP impressions, (2) brand attitude and (3) purchase intention.

Being exposed to a VR brand environment is assumed to offer a much more profound experience in which the human senses are addressed far more intensely compared to in case of a 2D ad (Shih 1998). Moreover, using VR technology compared to a 2D ad to convey a transformational brand message is expected to not only enhance consumers’ sensory stimulation (e.g. proprioception—a sense of position and movement; Sanchez-Vives and Slater 2005) but also make them experience flow (i.e. the feeling of being completely absorbed by an activity; Nah et al. 2011), immersion (i.e. the feeling of being isolated from the real world by means of a virtual environment; Witmer and Singer 1998) and presence (i.e. the feeling of being ‘there’; Sheridan 1992), which are in turn expected to facilitate the transference of BP impressions.

VR as a driver of brand personality

Prior research has demonstrated that advertising innovation can be a driver in the elicitation of BP (Bhat and Bowonder 2001). For instance, a 360-degree representation of a pair of sneakers versus an AR representation of that same product has been found to bring about more pronounced perceptions of brand excitement (Stoyanova et al. 2015).

Likewise, VR can be expected to positively affect the execution of the advertisement, which may help bring across specific BP traits (cf. Eisend and Stokburger-Sauer 2013). Perceiving a sensation of flow has been established to lead to higher levels of enjoyment (Sherry 2004), while presence is a phenomenon that is related to entertainment (Hartmann et al. 2010; Kwon et al. 2013). As such, VR can enrich the consumer experience by providing a hedonic experience (Lau and Lee 2016; Verhagen et al. 2011) and would therefore ensure the prevalence of hedonic benefit claims (Lim and Ang 2008), thus stimulating the elicitation of more profound BP impressions (Eisend and Stokburger-Sauer 2013).

Moreover, compared to 2D advertising, VR is expected to provide a more pronounced brand experience, potentially involving sensory, affective, cognitive and behavioural consumer responses, which, according to Brakus et al. (2009), should engender more enunciated BP perceptions. Consumers exposed to VR will enjoy a fuller sensory brand experience as a result of the enhanced sensory stimulation (e.g. the sense of falling and moving around). They are also expected to enjoy a more affective experience, as they should perceive presence and feel more immersed in the experience, which has been established to enhance perceived emotions (Riva et al. 2007). They are also assumed to be triggered cognitively, as the VR experience should stimulate them and make them curious. Lastly, consumers are also anticipated to experience enhanced behavioural effects due to VR, as it can provide ‘bodily experiences’ due to the sense of movement and immersion provided by the medium. Thus, convinced that VR can virtually trigger several brand experience dimensions (namely sensory, affective, cognitive and behavioural) and supported by Brakus et al. (2009), who found that enhanced brand experiences lead to more pronounced perceptions of BP, it is expected that VR advertising compared to 2D advertising will elicit stronger BP impressions.

In particular, with respect to the BP dimension ‘sincerity’ (H1a), VR advertising is expected to result in stronger consumer impressions of brand sincerity compared to 2D advertising. After all, VR advertising is a more direct form of marketing communications (e.g. hands-on experiences) than traditional 2D (video) advertising (Mooy and Robben 2002). For example, VR advertising lets the user view the product or environment from all possible angles, from which the user could infer that the corresponding brand is transparent and provides reliable and unbiased information in its advertisement. As such, advertising via the VR medium gives more insight into the brand and its offerings overall, and the content conveyed via the medium is consequently likely to be considered more ‘sincere’ by consumers compared to less direct brand experiences, such as those conveyed in traditional 2D advertising.

With regard to ‘excitement’ (H1b), it has been proven that the additional graphical detail of VR representations evokes a higher sense of presence, which is related to excitement (Kwon et al. 2013). Therefore, we expect a VR brand representation to evoke higher impressions of excitement than a 2D brand representation.

Regarding ‘competence’ (H1c), the adoption of a VR medium for marketing communications could be an indication of how innovative a brand is (Pantano 2014). As such, consumers can consider a brand that offers VR to be more ‘competent’ than brands that lag behind in adopting VR technology. In this way, it is expected that the use of VR marketing communications—compared to traditional 2D content—will lead to higher consumer impressions of brand competence.

For ‘sophistication’ (H1d), previous research regarding website personality found proof for the fact that increasing levels of playfulness (e.g. the feeling of escaping everyday routine originating from absorbing activities that create intrinsic enjoyment; Mathwick et al. (2001)) induced a positive impact on impressions of sophistication. It is expected that a VR (vs. 2D) brand experience provides the user with the ‘feeling of escaping reality’ (Van Kerrebroeck et al. 2017b), which is expected to have a positive impact on impressions of brand sophistication.

Furthermore, a VR experience gives the user more feedback on his or her movements (e.g. looking around in real life makes it possible to look around in the mediated environment) (Steuer 1992). Consequently, this evokes a higher physical presence than a normal 2D experience in which the user does not have the control to freely look around in the environment. Because former research has found that physical presence is a positive mediator of interactive VR experiences on the impressions of brand ruggedness (Jin 2010), we expect to validate these findings regarding ‘ruggedness’ (H1e) in this study, and we further complement them by explicitly comparing VR and 2D marketing communications in terms of the level of brand ruggedness perceptions evoked by each medium.

We therefore propose the following hypotheses:

H 1a

VR advertising will result in stronger consumer impressions of brand sincerity than 2D advertising.

H 1b

VR advertising will result in stronger consumer impressions of brand excitement than 2D advertising.

H 1c

VR advertising will result in stronger consumer impressions of brand competence than 2D advertising.

H 1d

VR advertising will result in stronger consumer impressions of brand sophistication than 2D advertising.

H 1e

VR advertising will result in stronger consumer impressions of brand ruggedness than 2D advertising.

Brand attitude and purchase intentions

Aside from anticipating a greater impact of VR advertising compared to traditional 2D advertising on BP impressions, brand attitude and purchase intentions are also expected to be affected more positively when consumers are exposed to this novel advertising technology (e.g. Van der Heijden et al. 2003; Aaker and Jacobson 2001). While the goal of transformational advertising is less conversion or sales related and pertains more to building and sustaining a favourable brand image and keeping the target consumer base interested, we do consider ‘purchase intentions’ because it involves an important, popular and often-used construct by both marketing scholars and practitioners (Spears and Singh 2004; Chiu et al. 2014). It also reflects an important longer-term marketing communications objective. In fact, purchase intentions have been demonstrated to correlate particularly well with actual purchase behaviour when studying existing products (vs. new), durable products (vs. non-durable) and when specific brands (vs. broader categories of products) are considered (Morwitz et al. 2007).

Given the immersive nature of VR technology, advertising via this new medium can be expected to have a more positive effect on brand attitude and purchase intentions compared with traditional 2D advertising. The representational richness of a medium has previously been established to evoke feelings of presence and consequently to generate more positive consumer attitudes towards a brand and higher purchase intentions (Choi and Taylor 2014; Fennis et al. 2012; Klein 2003; Stoyanova et al. 2015). As such, we propose the following hypotheses:

H 2

VR advertising will result in a more positive brand attitude than 2D advertising.

H 3

VR advertising will result in higher purchase intentions than 2D advertising.

Methodology

Stimuli and procedure

The study involves an experimental between-subjects design that focuses on branding outcomes while considering the brand The North Face, an outdoor clothing and accessories brand. Differentiation in the fashion/apparel sector is quintessential due to the threat of fast fashion retailers (e.g. Zara or H&M; Willems et al. 2012). High-class/premium fashion retailers, such as The North Face or Jack Wolfskin, are put in an unfavourable position by fast fashion retailers, as consumers are becoming more demanding (Bhardwaj and Fairhurst 2010) and are more eager to buy cheap, fashionable clothing (Bruce and Daly 2006). For example, H&M started selling outdoor clothing as part of their new sports collection (Bromiley 2017) at relatively more affordable prices than The North Face or other higher-class outdoor brands. Investments in branding and BP are required if these upscale brands are to sustain their role in the present competition. For this experiment, The North Face was chosen because it is a well-known brand and the label entails products that are suitable for both women and men (Goldsmith and Goldsmith 2012). The core market of The North Face is not a specific age group but consists of a rather broad segment (men, women and kids) who like living an active and adventurous lifestyle (The North Face 2017). In order to attract not only adults but also millennials, the company recently invested in a mobile campaign to raise brand awareness among 18- to 34-year-olds (Millennialmedia 2015). Also, this brand was one of the first in its category to provide a VR experience (Yin 2015).

The experiment took place in a classroom setting, and the respondents were randomly assigned to one of the two conditions (2D or VR). Participants were individually exposed to one treatment (2D or VR) at a time in the classroom setting; thus, both groups were studied separately and in isolation. In the first condition, participants were subjected to a 2D advertisement via a YouTube videoFootnote 2 on an Android smartphone. The video showed athletes rock climbing in Yosemite National Park. In the second condition, the participants were subjected to a VR advertisement via a Google Cardboard-type VR headset, using the same Android smartphone. In this case, the respondents used the VR-enabled app ‘The North Face: Climb’ (Jaunt 2015). The VR application allows users to feel as if they are actually participating themselves in an adventurous rock-climbing experience in Yosemite National Park and allows them to look around 360 degrees as well as to perceive the sensation of, for instance, jumping off a cliff with a parachute. Thus, the VR-based ad offers a richer, more complex, vivid and immersive 3-dimensional experience, allowing proprioceptor-based stimulation (i.e. the feeling of height and being able to fall), as compared to the simple 2D ad, which offers only a ‘flat’ video viewing experience. Also, due to its true full screen display technology, the VR medium is able to block out the real surrounding environment, causing a higher level of immersion in the scenery of the ad. The mere fact that the VR headset is fully encompassing the user’s sight also causes less distraction from the outside world, as compared to the mobile 2D ad, which is only shown on a small smartphone screen making it rather easy to look away. Apart from these medium-specific differences, other more content-related elements in the experimental stimuli were held constant between groups. For example, the scenery in both advertisements was comparable, the length was approximately the same (3 min), and the background music was identical in both formats. Both conditions are considered non-interactive (e.g. the user ‘sees’ climbing sessions performed by others, whereby he or she cannot really interact with the environment, except for looking around in it). The advertising format used can generally be classified as transformational (i.e. the advertisement focuses on the experience of using the product in a relevant environment rather than providing functional information such as product specifications). As such, the two advertising conditions only differed in terms of the ‘medium’ or ‘message representation’: 2D versus VR (cf. Van Kerrebroeck et al. 2017a). It was also not possible to buy products directly from either of these media.

Measures

Aaker’s framework has been proven to be appropriate to explore hypotheses regarding antecedents and consequences of BP (Austin et al. 2003, p. 88). The questionnaire in this study consisted of a pre- and post-measurement of the BP impressions of The North Face, gauged according to Aaker’s (1997) BP construct which comprises five BP dimensions measured by fourteen 7-point Likert scale items (ranging from ‘1’ strongly disagree to ‘7’ strongly agree). The pre-measurements were captured before participants were exposed to either the 2D or VR advertisement in order to control for potential a priori differences in BP impressions between the two groups. An internal consistency check was performed for each of the five dimensions: sincerity (three items; α = 0.764; e.g. ‘honest’), excitement (three items; α = 0.702; e.g. ‘daring’), competence (three items; α = 0.739; e.g. ‘reliable’), sophistication (two items; r = 0.248; p < 0.001; e.g. ‘upper class’) and ruggedness (two items; r = 0.503; p < 0.001; e.g. ‘tough’).

Furthermore, brand attitude and purchase intentions were measured by means of, respectively, three (α = 0.868; e.g. ‘like/dislike’) and two (r = 0.914; p < 0.001; e.g. ‘likely/unlikely to purchase’) items on 7-point semantic differential scales (adapted from Homer 1990). As we conducted this study in a classroom (lab) setting and not in an actual store and the brand experience ‘The North Face: Climb’ does not include any option to buy products directly from the app, nor does it link the viewer to the brand’s website, direct purchases were not possible in this experiment and could therefore not be assessed. However, as this study focuses on a specific brand of an existing, durable product category (i.e. outdoor apparel), we can, according to Morwitz et al. (2007), assume a strong, positive relationship between the measured intentions and consumers’ eventual purchase behaviour.

Finally, vividness (Keller and Block 1997; six items; α = 0.836; e.g. ‘not easy to imagine/easy to imagine’) and presence (adapted from Coyle and Thorson 2001; eight items; α = 0.880, after deletion of items six and eight; e.g. ‘While I was watching the movie, I felt like I was in the world The North Face created’) were measured as manipulation checks. Vividness experienced in the VR condition appeared significantly higher than in the 2D condition (independent samples t test: mVR = 5.48; SD = 0.83 vs. m2D = 4.76; SD = 1.11; p < 0.001). Similarly, we found that the VR representation scored significantly higher in terms of presence (independent samples t test: mVR = 4.42; SD = 1.06 vs. m2D = 3.54; SD = 1.38; p < 0.001). Given the differences in vividness and presence between both conditions, we can conclude that respondents in the VR condition can indeed be assumed to have been more intensively immersed in the advertisement.

The full list of items pertaining to the measured constructs is available in “Appendix” section.

Sampling and participant information

The sample involved a convenience sample of 160 Belgian students, who were intercepted at the university campus and were randomly assigned to one of the two experimental conditions (2D or VR) according to a matched-pairs design as far as gender is concerned in order to avoid any potential demographic confounds (Nam 1997). This resulted in 80 usable responses per condition. A Pearson Chi-square test indicated no asymmetry in gender dispersion due to the matched-pairs design (χ2(1) = 0.400; p = 0.527). The average age of the respondents was 23.19 (SD = 2.57, age range 20–35), which is an adequate representation of the target group The North Face would like to reach with its VR advertising. An independent samples t test indicated that the respondents were also evenly spread over the conditions as far as age is concerned [t(157) = 1.668; p = 0.097].

The use of student samples is common practice in social psychology and consumer behaviour research (Peterson 2001; Simonson et al. 2001; Peterson and Merunka 2014), as they provide a degree of homogeneity ensuring comparability within the sample. Particularly when enquiring about personal opinions and individual decisions, student samples are considered adequate (McKnight et al. 2002). While differences within student samples could occur, these would be rather low because younger participants are usually more familiar with and open to technology (e.g. VR) (Venkatesh, Thong and Xu 2012). The use of a student sample in this particular study is specifically justified, as millennials are actually the target the brand The North Face aims to reach by the implementation of innovative marketing communication techniques.

Millennials are of specific interest to current marketers because this target group forms the future customer base (Mueller et al. 2011). In order to stay relevant in the coming years, brands must reinvent themselves to fulfil the needs of millennials who are looking for technology-assisted shopping experiences (Barton et al. 2012). Millennials form strong enduring brand preferences and are especially important for fashion brands, as both men and women in this generation tend to be passionate about clothing (accordingly, they are sometimes referred to as ‘clotheshorses’) (Barton et al. 2012). While this young generation might not have enough or sufficient spending power at present, they will have a higher disposable income when they grow older, which will allow them to translate their brand preference into actual demand. Forward-looking companies must therefore connect with this generation today to reap the benefits in the coming future (Barton et al. 2012). One way of making the connection with this generation is by focusing on shopping experiences such as VR.

Findings

Brand personality dimensions

As the research design implied that participants were randomly assigned to either of two treatments (2D or VR), no a priori differences in existing BP impressions were expected. As anticipated, independent samples t tests revealed no significant differences for four out of five pre-BP measurements, for example ‘ruggedness’ (mVRpre = 5.78; SD = 1.10 vs. m2Dpre = 5.56; SD = 1.127; t(156) = − 1.288; p (two-tailed) = 0.200). However, for the BP dimension ‘sincerity’, there did appear to be a significant difference between the two groups prior to being exposed to the treatment [mVRpre = 4.87; SD = 0.80 vs. m2Dpre = 4.54; SD = 0.91; t(158) = − 2.418; p (two-tailed) = 0.017]. For that reason, analyses of covariance (ANCOVA) were conducted to identify differences in impact on the five BP dimensions (i.e. the dependent variables) between the two different advertising media 2D and VR (i.e. the grouping variable), using the respective pre-BP measurements as covariates.

The ANCOVA yielded significant differences between the 2D and the VR advertisement treatments for three of the five BP dimensions, namely in terms of impressions of brand ‘excitement’ and ‘sophistication’, as well as a marginal effect for ‘ruggedness’. The by-the-ad-generated levels of brand excitement (H1b) were significantly higher in the VR condition as compared to in the 2D condition [mVR = 5.75; SD = 0.90 vs. m2D = 5.13; SD = 1.01; F(1156) = 18.23, p < 0.001 (one-tailed)] (cf. Table 1). Furthermore, VR also appeared to generate a higher level of brand sophistication over 2D advertising (H1d) [mVR = 4.49; SD = 1.10 vs. m2D = 4.01; SD = 0.96; F(1156) = 8.70, p (one-tailed) = 0.002]. In addition, in line with the expectations, a marginally significant effect was found with regard to the perceived level of brand ruggedness (H1e), with ruggedness levels being higher in the case of VR (mVR = 6.21; SD = 0.93 vs. 2D; m2D = 5.92; SD = 1.04; F(1154) = 1.988, p (one-tailed) = 0.081). Thus, hypotheses H1b (excitement) and H1d (sophistication) can be accepted, while H1e (ruggedness) can be marginally accepted (cf. Table 1).

The robustness of the ANCOVA results was evaluated by performing five simple linear regression analyses. For each BP dimension separately, the post-measurement was used as the dependent variable, while the pre-measurement was used as the predictor. The standardized residuals were saved, and the mean values were compared between the control and test group (i.e. 2D vs. VR setting) in five independent samples t tests, addressing H1a to H1e. The conclusion was the same as that inferred from the ANCOVA results, namely that VR instils significantly higher perceptions of brand excitement and sophistication than 2D (and marginally higher perceptions of ruggedness), confirming H1b, H1d and H1e, albeit marginally for the last hypothesis (NB: further details on the regression results can be obtained upon request from the authors). To conclude, the differences in BP impressions between the pre- and post-measurements (for 2D and VR) are visually represented in Fig. 1. The significant differences between the two groups on excitement and sophistication, as tested according to Table 1, can be easily derived from this graph.

Brand attitude and purchase intentions

Independent samples t tests were conducted to examine whether ‘attitude towards the brand’ and ‘purchase intentions’ were rated significantly higher in the VR condition than in the 2D condition. The results indicated that respondents who viewed the VR advertisement indeed exhibited statistically significantly more positive attitudes towards the brand [mVR = 5.40; SD = 0.86 vs. m2D = 4.89; SD = 0.88; t(157) = − 3.656; p (one-tailed) < 0.001] and significantly higher purchase intentions [mVR = 4.23; SD = 1.34 vs. m2D = 3.62; SD = 1.67; t(151,134) = − 2.533; p (one-tailed) = 0.006].

Discussion

Theoretical implications

The purpose of this study was to investigate the superior impact of VR as an advertising format (as compared to the 2D format) on perceived BP, attitude towards the brand and purchase intentions. As such, this study is one of the first of its kind to investigate and demonstrate the impact of VR advertising on several important brand outcome variables by identifying VR advertising as an antecedent of BP and as a driver of brand attitudes and purchase intentions (Eisend and Stokburger-Sauer 2013). Therefore, this research paves the way to a virtually unexploited area of how VR advertising can be a vehicle for brand managers to bring their brands to life while reaping the rewards in terms of more positive consumer responses.

By means of a between-subjects design, we could not only confirm that, in the case of an outdoor apparel brand, VR advertising could contribute more effectively to the BP dimensions of ‘excitement’, ‘sophistication’ and to some extent ‘ruggedness’ than 2D advertising (Hypotheses H1b, H1d and H1e) but also that it had a stronger impact on crucial consumer response variables such as brand attitude (Hypothesis 2) and purchase intentions (Hypothesis 3). As such, the findings regarding the impact of VR on BP are largely in line with the expectations. Not all BP dimensions were significantly affected, which may be because not all dimensions were equally addressed in the particular VR application used (i.e. content/message of the transformational brand experience conveyed). Alternatively, it may be due to the brand specifically, as all brands evidently differ (and should differ) in terms of their personality (Grohmann 2009). Last, regarding the impact of VR on brand attitude and purchase intentions, the findings matched the expectations (e.g. Choi and Taylor 2014; Stoyanova et al. 2015), as both constructs were positively affected by the VR experience.

Practical implications

The main practical implication of this research is that it provides key insights into brand managers regarding the effectiveness of VR advertising to bring their brands to life. The findings reveal that with the aid of this novel, computer-mediated advertising medium, brands such as the outdoor apparel and accessories brand The North Face can emphasize their BP with respect to the dimensions ‘excitement’, ‘sophistication’ and ‘ruggedness’ more effectively than with traditional 2D advertising. For The North Face’s existing and potential client base, being profiled and seen as ‘exciting’ is meaningful, as it is essentially what the segment is looking for in this product category. The more pronounced elicitation of the dimension ‘sophistication’ should also add more value to the brand. Fundamentally, The North Face’s ‘all-weather-protection’ equipment (The North Face 2017) is profiled as high standing and classy. As such, the brand should clearly benefit from these enhanced BP impressions. Moreover, this experiment indicates that brand attitudes and purchase intentions were significantly higher for consumers exposed to the VR advertisement as compared to the 2D version. Given the findings of previous research, it can be expected that the above outcomes will also get translated into actual purchase behaviour (Eisend and Stokburger-Sauer 2013).

For brands in other categories, the findings may provide an incentive to focus on the creation of hedonic VR brand content, as there seems to be an urgent call for generating relevant content that creates valuable brand experiences (Crabtree 2016). In particular, they may be interested in catering to the perhaps less obvious BP traits, which were not found elicited in this research but still may be very relevant to certain brands. For example, ‘sincerity’ and ‘competence’ are two important BP dimensions in the business of economy hotels (Litvin et al. 2016). Hotel managers can implement VR in their communication strategy and adjust the message content in order to emphasize these desired BP associations. This can be done, for example, by representing their hotel rooms in VR so the customer can view all aspects of the room. This shows that the hotel chain has ‘nothing to hide’ and thus can be seen as more sincere.

Limitations and suggestions for further research

While this study sheds light on the merits of VR in an advertising context to enhance BP impressions, brand attitudes and purchase intentions, some limitations must be taken into account. First, the data collected are based on a student sample. This may affect the generalizability of the findings (Mazaheri et al. 2012), as age is considered a moderator with regard to the adoption of new technologies (Venkatesh et al. 2003). As such, further research could clarify whether age also affects the transmission of BP via VR.

Moreover, as the technology under study is not yet widespread in consumer markets, users may have experienced a novelty effect (Jin 2010), potentially biasing the consumer responses positively after exposure to a new and exciting technology. Hence, further research may consider a longitudinal approach in order to examine the long-term impact of the technology for advertising purposes. Similarly, the impact of consumer innovativeness or technology readiness as a moderator could also be taken into consideration (Goldsmith and Hofacker 1991; Parasuraman and Colby 2015).

When considering VR advertising as an experience, it currently is to be mapped as a rather passive, non-interactive technology on the customer participation axis in frameworks such as that of Pine and Gilmore (1998) or Van Kerrebroeck et al. (2017a). VR users in this study could sit back and take in the experience they were offered. As other VR applications which enable more active participation (e.g. real estate applications in which users can self-navigate through various rooms or retail applications in which the shopper can navigate in the store and actually take products off the shelves in order to get a closer look) also exist, further research could investigate how a higher degree of interactivity affects consumer responses. Even when the experience is rather passive, the ease of use of the required device could also be taken into account (e.g. the Technology Acceptance Model or UTAUT; Venkatesh et al. 2003; Davis 1989). VR, as compared to, for instance, AR, requires specific equipment which the user needs to put on (e.g. a headset). Depending on the circumstances, this technology may thus be easier or more difficult to use. When offering the technology in store, for instance, it is ‘provided’ to the consumer by the retailer. On the other hand, it requires more effort to use VR at home, and advanced headsets cannot be used on the go (unlike mobile Google Cardboard-like devices, which are to be used with a smartphone).

Although effects on BP were found in this study, which seemed to positively affect subsequent consumer responses regarding brand attitudes and purchase intentions, such effects were not found for the BP dimensions of sincerity and competence, which, according to a meta-analysis by Eisend and Stokburger-Sauer (2013), are, however, strong determinants of brand success measures. As this may be due to the specific brand and product category under study and/or the particular ad content used, replications of this study are called for. For example, further research could investigate the impact of 2D versus VR advertising on BP impressions for different brands within the same branch (e.g. comparing different apparel brands such as The North Face vs. Jack Wolfskin) as well as for brands in different branches (e.g. comparing brands in apparel, nutrition, automotive or even insurance industries). While the first wave of extensions to this study could be able to strengthen the findings for one particular branch, the latter entails the possibility to find consistencies in the transfer of BP impressions over different branches (e.g. are certain BP dimensions conveyed better via VR in particular branches?). Different brands can possibly put a different emphasis on which of the five BP dimensions they want to portray in their strategies. For example, while charity organizations might consider emphasizing ‘sincerity’ and ‘competence’, youth clothing brands might be inclined to put more emphasis on ‘excitement’ and ‘ruggedness’. After all, strategic brand management involves the decision upon and building of a specific BP (Keller 2009) for a company to present itself as a unique brand to the consumer (Malär et al. 2012).

According to our analyses, there also seemed to be only a marginal impact of the advertising medium (i.e. VR vs. 2D) on the dimension of ‘ruggedness’ of Aaker’s (1997) BP conceptualization, although the brand under study (i.e. The North Face) clearly presents itself in such a way. For example, as the website design implies (The North Face 2017), direct links can be made with an outdoorsy and tough personality (e.g. people who enjoy skiing, rock climbing and working out). This may explain why respondents already rated ruggedness, which consists of the items ‘outdoorsy’ and ‘tough’, quite high in the pre-questionnaire (mpre(2D+VR) = 5.67), resulting in only a marginal additional effect of VR over 2D advertising (p = 0.081). This points to a possible ceiling effect; that is, as the brand is already rated high on this BP dimension, the VR medium will have little added value in enhancing the perception of this particular BP dimension (Ang and Lim 2006). As such, this dimension of BP was only significantly affected by the manipulation at the 10% level. In order to further test the appropriateness of VR compared to traditional 2D advertising in bringing across specific BP dimensions and further validate the findings, more experiments could be conducted, using other, perhaps less prototypical or even unknown, brands, preferably also belonging to different product categories. In addition, further research could also consider different VR ad appeals and brand experiences, in order to identify how particular BP traits can best be elicited using VR. Such further research could confirm the robustness of this study’s finding that VR is more powerful than 2D advertising in generating certain BP impressions among consumers.

Further research could also apply field experiments to verify the impact of VR advertisements on actual purchase behaviour. This could be done at flagship stores (such as the flagship store of The North Face in South Korea), as their main objective is to build brand image and enhance positive brand attitudes (Dolbec and Chebat 2013), and shoppers who are persuaded by the VR experience can also immediately buy products there. As such, it would be interesting to investigate the impact of VR in such experience stores on actual purchase behaviour and purchase loyalty.

Also, the function of VR advertisements in relation to the ‘sales funnel’ (cf. Willems et al. 2016, 2017) could be studied. For example, are VR advertisements more suitable to people who are interested in purchasing the product (potential buyers who already have the brand in their consideration set) or to make people familiar with the brand (consumers who are aware of the brand and might become interested)? And is different content (e.g. informational vs. transformational) more suitable in certain conditions?

Finally, while this VR application addresses the senses of vision, hearing and proprioception, other human senses such as touch or smell have not yet been addressed. Yet, these senses are atmospheric elements that can impact customer experiences (e.g. Bosmans 2006; Doucé et al. 2013; Van Kerrebroeck et al. 2017c) and that have also been proven to further increase the user’s perceived presence in the virtual environment (e.g. Jin 2010; Serrano et al. 2016), contributing to delivering an even more immersive environment. Hence, further studies could examine the impact of additional sensory elements via VR applications for branding purposes, such as the rich sensory experience offered by the hotel chain Marriott International (Mandelbaum 2015).
